Freedom the benefits of the excitement

about well look something happened to me
um but I even saying that kind of puts
it in a little bit too passive of a
voice you know um I set out to I set out
looking for something very specific and
through a pretty rigorous search um and
and a pretty rigorous set of practices I
I got that thing that I wanted which to
put it really simply and perhaps overs
simply um is is a certain calmness you
know um it's life is an extremely
agitating event you know and and I
vibrate at a slightly higher frequency
than is necessarily healthy you know um
and I always have I've always been kind
of anxious I've always been super
emotive um I feel things harder than is
good for me um uh indecision has been
part of my life you know and and I could
see after a certain age how that was
destructive not only to myself but to
people around me and you know I just
think you get to a point where you don't
want to be in other people's way you
know you don't want to be taking up um
you don't want to be taking up other
people's space and energies to sort of
take care of you and and I longed to be
a different kind of person you know I
longed to be just a little more at ease
a little more relaxed um and and a
little more wise you know because it
seems to me that wisdom is the beginning
of of Serenity you know um and you know
aside from people who are very heavily

tend to also be the wisest um who are
quickest you know or more most
instinctively able to put things in a

the works you know those practices
work and people do it um in different
ways and they do it they do it in

end result and the end desire is always

not in the world then at least within

I Glide through the world now on a sort

because I am you know exactly as capable

service representative putting you on
hold rage and all the other sorts of
rages and and jealousies and
frustrations and um and self-pity I mean
all these things are not foreign to me
you know but I've just I don't know it's
like there's an engine that works within
me now that much much much more
efficiently processes all of that um and
and I you know I believe and know that
that's a direct result of the work that
I did for a whole bunch of years you
know um trying to get to that place
place and when I find myself kind of
spinning out of orbit you know there's
like a tether you know um that that that
I braided you know myself um from my own
beliefs and my own studies and this work
you know and that tether sort of pulls
me back and reminds me do you really
want to go you really want to make a big
production out of this or would it be
better for you and everybody around you
if you just found a way to accept what's
going on on um and and that's just made
life very much more pleasant and and I

spiritual practice today it is the
maintenance of that um it is doing
whatever is necessary to keep that
healthy um and to keep that system
working and and you have to be a little
bit Nimble and a little bit flexible to
kind of figure out what each day
requires um in order to keep that
going um I find to be perfectly honest a
lot of it has to do with
napping you know I just think you know
I'm I'm I'm alarmed by by reports of how
little sleep Americans are getting
anymore you know even in the last 10
years people are getting on average you
know an hour to two hours less sleep a
day it's making people really frazzled
and really fragile and I just I kind of
feel like you know if there's a new
religion that needs to be founded it's a
it's a religion about like
naps um you know something happens when
you take a nap you go into another state
you're you know you're pulse goes down
your blood pressure goes down um it's a
kind of meditation it's a kind of loose
meditation um and uh I do a lot of it
seems to help um seems to make me more
pleasant to the people around me I would
prescribe it to anybody I think every
nation that has any
civility incorporates napping into their
day in a kind of official way so um you
know rest rest I say no to a lot of
things that's become a kind of active
spiritual practice for me I turn down a
lot of things um not just professional
invitations but personal invitations and
social invitations um I think saying no
is something we're really bad at in this
culture um I spent years not saying no
to anything because I was afraid that if
I said no to people they wouldn't like
me as much and they would be
disappointed and I've learned in my old
age that when you say no to people they
don't like you as much and they're
disappointed nonetheless you know there
are times when it has to be done in
order to protect whatever small sanctity
of serenity have built up in your life
it's inhumane the pace at which people
live um in this society and and when I
came back from traveling from me pray
love I was I was truly sort of
jaw-droppingly shocked um to see it a
new from fresh eyes and to see the
amount of stress and the amount of work
that we have somehow decided is normal
um and it is so warped and my you know
fear is that we've exported that you
know and we're sort of exporting that
idea all over the world all the time and
sort of spreading it like a virus and
it's just there is no there is
absolutely no way you can defend it as
as healthy normal safe or wise and yet
it's really hard to resist and you have
to push really hard against it you know
um and I don't always succeed you know I
find myself at the end of my rope all
the time I'm like how did I end up how
do I end up with a 14-hour day today
like why you know how did how did I let
that happen um and and so there's a sort
of vigilance um against that that I
would really strongly argue as part of
like the main spiritual practice of my
